template.template: Template App Windows Active Directory Security
template.name: Template App Windows Active Directory Security
template.description:
This template allows you to check locked, disabled users and events from Windows security log related with Windows Domain Controller security.
Note: All monitors (except “Locked out users” and “Disabled users”) should return zero values. Returned values other than zero may indicate an abnormality, but not always. In any case, you should examine the Windows security log file for details (are this action permitted in your organization or not).
Portions of this document were originally created by and are excerpted from the following sources:
Microsoft Corporation, “TechNet Library,” Copyright © 2017 Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved. Available at http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd277397.aspx

item.name: Logon: Account failed to log on count
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of failed login events with incorrect username or password.
Event ID: 4625.
Check for attempts where Target Account Name equals Administrator or the renamed default administrator account. Check multiple logon failures that are below the account lockout threshold.

item.name: System: The system time was changed
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when somebody changes system time.
Event ID: 520.
This event indicates the old and new system time as well as who did it as specified in the Subject: section. It is routine to see this event where subject is "LOCAL SERVICE" and can probably be ignored. You will frequently see this event logged twice in a row for whatever reason.

item.name: System: Windows is shutting down
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when Windows goes to shut down.
Event ID: 4609.
On high-value computers, authorized personnel should restart computers in accordance with established policies. Investigate immediately when this event occurs on any server.

item.name: Logon: Account failed to log on
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of failed login events with incorrect username or password.
Event ID: 4625.
Check for attempts where Target Account Name equals Administrator or the renamed default administrator account. Check multiple logon failures that are below the account lockout threshold.

item.name: Logon: Attempted logon using explicit credentials
Logon: Replay attack detected
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when the authentication package (usually Kerberos) detects an attempt to log on by replay of a user's credentials.
Event ID: 4649.
Investigate immediately. Alternatively, this could be a sign of incorrect network configuration.

item.name: System: Service installed in the system
item.description:
his monitor returns the number of events when a new service was installed by the user indicated in the subject.
Event ID: 4697.
Subject often identifies the local system (SYSTEM) for services installed as part of native Windows components and therefore you can't determine who actually initiated the installation. This is a key change control event as new services are significant extensions of the software running on a server and the roles it performs.

item.name: Policy: Kerberos policy was changed
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when Windows detects a change to the the domain's Kerberos policy. Kerberos policy is defined in GPOs linked to the root of the domain under Computer Configuration\Windows Settings\Security Settings\Account Policy\Kerberos Policy.
Event ID: 4713.
Unfortunately, the Subject fields don't identify who actually changed the policy because this policy isn't directly configured by administrators. Instead, it is edited in a group policy object which then gets applied to the computer. Therefore, this event always shows the local computer as the one who changed the policy since the computer is the security principal under which gpupdate runs.

item.name: Policy: Encrypted data recovery policy was changed
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when computer's Security Settings\Public Key Policies\Encrypting File System data recovery agent policy was modified - either via Local Security Policy or Group Policy in Active Directory.
Event ID: 4714.
Unfortunately, the Subject fields don't identify who actually changed the policy because this policy isn't directly configured by administrators. Instead, it is edited in a group policy object which then gets applied to the computer. Therefore, this event always shows the local computer as the one who changed the policy since the computer is the security principal under which gpupdate runs.

item.name: Policy: System audit policy was changed
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when computer's system level audit policy was modified - either via Local Security Policy, Group Policy in Active Directory or the audipol command.
Event ID: 4719.
According to Microsoft, this event is always logged when an audit policy is disabled, regardless of the "Audit Policy Change" sub-category setting. If group policy was used to configure audit policy unfortunately the Subject fields don't identify who actually changed the policy. In such cases this event always shows the local computer as the one who changed the policy since the computer is the security principal under which gpupdate runs. This event does not necessarily indicate a problem. However, an attacker can change audit policy as part of a computer system attack. You should monitor for this event on high value computers and domain controllers.

item.name: User Account: User account was created
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events of creating new user accounts.
Event ID: 4720.
Only authorized people and processes should create network accounts. Examine the Primary User Name field to detect whether an authorized person or process created an account. This event also detects if administrators create accounts outside organizational policy guidelines.

item.name: User Account: Attempt to change password
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when somebody tries to change accounts password.
Event ID: 4723.
This event is logged as a failure if his new password fails to meet the password policy. This event results from a password change request in which the user supplies the original password to the account. Compare Primary Account Name to Target Account Name to determine whether the account owner or someone else attempted to change the password. If Primary Account Name does not equal Target Account Name, someone other than the account owner tried to change the password.

item.name: User Account: Attempt to reset password
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when a user or process resets an account password through an administrative interface such as Active Directory Users and Computers, rather than through a password change process.
Event ID: 4724.
This event is logged as a failure if the new password fails to meet the password policy. Only authorized people or processes should carry out this process, such as help desk or user self-service password reset.

item.name: User Account: Account was disabled
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when account becomes disabled.
Event ID: 4725.
Always investigate this event.

item.name: User Account: Account was deleted
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events of deleting user accounts.
Event ID: 4726.
Only authorized people and processes should delete network accounts. Search for these events and examine the Primary Account Name field to detect if unauthorized people have deleted accounts.

item.name: User Account: Account was changed
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when changes were made to security-related properties of user accounts.
Event ID: 4738.

item.name: Policy: Domain policy was changed
item.description:
his monitor returns the number of events when the computer's Security Settings\Account Policy or Account Lockout Policy was modified - either via Local Security Policy or Group Policy in Active Directory.
Event ID: 4739.
Unfortunately, the Subject fields don't identify who actually changed the policy because this policy isn't directly configured by administrators. Instead, it is edited in a group policy object which then gets applied to the computer. Therefore, this event always shows the local computer as the one who changed the policy since the computer is the security principal under which gpupdate runs.

item.name: User Account: Account was locked out
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of automatically locked out accounts.
Event ID: 4740.
A user account has locked out because the number of sequential failed logon attempts is greater than the account lockout limit.

item.name: User Account: Account name was changed
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when user changes the normal logon name or the pre-Win2k logon name
Event ID: 4781.
When an account name is changed, the SID remains the same. However the Target ID in this event indicates the new name. This is because when the operating system displays this event it evidently queries the database where the SID is stored and translates the SID to the domain\username. A rogue admin might change his account name or computer name seeking to cover his tracks.

item.name: System: Windows Firewall setting has changed
item.description:
This monitor returns the number of events when changes were made via the Windows Firewall with Advanced Services MMC console.
Event ID: 4950.

trigger.name: Logon: Account failed to log on {HOST.NAME} is very high

trigger.expression: {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4649].logeventid(4649)}=1 and {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4649].nodata(60)}<>1
trigger.name: Logon: Replay attack detected on {HOST.NAME}

trigger.expression: {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4739].logeventid(4739)}=1 and {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4739].nodata(60)}<>1
trigger.name: Policy: Domain policy was changed on {HOST.NAME}

trigger.expression: {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4714].logeventid(4714)}=1 and {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4714].nodata(60)}<>1
trigger.name: Policy: Encrypted data recovery policy was changed on {HOST.NAME}

trigger.expression: {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4713].logeventid(4713)}=1 and {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4713].nodata(60)}<>1
trigger.name: Policy: Kerberos policy was changed on {HOST.NAME}

trigger.expression: {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4719].logeventid(4719)}=1 and {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4719].nodata(60)}<>1
trigger.name: Policy: System audit policy was changed on {HOST.NAME}

trigger.expression: {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4697].logeventid(4697)}=1 and {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4697].nodata(60)}<>1
trigger.name: System: Service installed in the system on {HOST.NAME}

trigger.expression: {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,520].logeventid(520)}=1 and {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,520].nodata(60)}<>1
trigger.name: System: The system time was changed on {HOST.NAME}

trigger.expression: {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4950].logeventid(4950)}=1 and {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4950].nodata(60)}<>1
trigger.name: System: Windows Firewall setting has changed on {HOST.NAME}

trigger.expression: {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4609].logeventid(4609)}=1 and {Template App Windows Active Directory Security:eventlog["Security",,,,4609].nodata(60)}<>1
trigger.name: System: Windows is shutting down on {HOST.NAME}
